column5: I fired off an E-Mail to the MNR regarding this topic.  My question..........  Q:  Is it legal or illegal to have a fire directly on the ice , ie:frozen waterway.. must it be contained? like in a stove or bucket or portable pit, chimmnea?  A: from E-mail Reply: Yes Hello Randy,  Thank you for your enquiry. Under the Public Lands Act;  Unauthorized filling -  27. (1) Except with the written consent of the Minister or an officer authorized by the Minister, no person shall deposit or cause to be deposited any material, substance or thing,  (a) on public lands, whether or not the lands are covered with water or ice; or  ( on water or ice covering public lands. 2010, c. 16, Sched. 10, s. 4 (2).  Having a fire on a frozen water body would leave debris and ash on the ice surface, which would be considered 'deposited material'. Therefore you can't have a fire directly on the ice of a lake or river. You may have a fire in a barrel or other contained vessel as long as it's removed after use and leaves no trace behind.  We hope you find this information helpful. If you require further assistance, please contact the Natural Resources Information Centre at 1-800-667-1940.
